review.title: Detecting and Extracting Events from Text Documents
review.abstract: Events of various kinds are mentioned and discussed in text documents, whether they are books, news articles, blogs or microblog feeds. The paper starts by giving an overview of how events are treated in linguistics and philosophy. We follow this discussion by surveying how events and associated information are handled in computationally. In particular, we look at how textual documents can be mined to extract events and ancillary information. These days, it is mostly through the application of various machine learning techniques. We also discuss applications of event detection and extraction systems, particularly in summarization, in the medical domain and in the context of Twitter posts. We end the paper with a discussion of challenges and future directions.

We also discuss applications of event detection and extraction systems, especially in summaries, in the medical field and in the context of Twitter posts. sections.heading: 2. EVENTS IN LINGUISTICS AND PHILOSOPHY
sections.text: In this section, we will give an overview of how real events are represented in relation to language. In particular, we will discuss the classification of events and characteristics that are necessary for such a classification. Afterwards, we will present the preferred way in which philosophers present events in relation to logic. We will end this section by presenting some of the structures attributed to events by linguists or philosophers working on an abstract level. The reason for including this section in the essay is to set the context for the discussions in the following sections on the practical task of extracting events. Practical systems usually do not follow linguistic subtleties, although they are inspired by linguistics or philosophy.

sections.text: The primary focus when linguists discuss events is on the verb present in a sentence. Nouns, adjectives and other elements present in a sentence provide arguments for the verb. Aristotle (as presented in [Barnes et al. 1984]) classified verbs that denote something into three classes: actuality, movement and action. An actuality represents the existence of a thing or thing; this is referred to by others as a state (e.g. [Rosen 1999]). An example of actuality can be seen in the sentence Jon: a movement is sick. A movement is an incomplete process or something that takes time but has no inherent end. An example of movement is in the sentence Jon runs. An action is something that takes time and has an inherent end. An example of an action is present in the sentence Jon.

sections.heading: 3.4 FrameNet
sections.text: FrameNet et al. 1998; Fillmore et al. 2003; Ruppenhofer et al. 2006] is another major publicly available lexical resource that has emerged independently of each other. It is based on the theory of frame semantics [Fillmore 1976; Petruck 1996; Fillmore and Baker 2001a; 2001b; Fillmore 2006], where a frame corresponds to a stereo-typical scenario with an interaction and participants in which the participants play some kind of role. The idea is that the meanings of most words are best understood in context. FrameNet proposes a small context called a semantic framework, a description of an event, relationship or entity and the participant in it. A frame has a name and this name is used to identify a semantic relationship that summarizes the semantic elements. Although frames largely correspond to verbs, there are frames that can be identified by nouns and adjectives.

sections.heading: 4.1 TimeML Events
sections.text: In the TimeML [Pustejovsky et al. 2003; Sauri et al. 2005] annotation scheme, an event is a generic term for situations that happen or occur. Events can be punctual or temporary, or last for a certain period of time. Events in TimeML format can also include predicates that describe states or circumstances in which something applies. Only the states participating in an opposition structure, as discussed in subsection 2.4.3, are commented on. Generally, an event can be expressed in the form of verbs, nominations, adjectives, predictive clauses, or prepositional phrases. TimeML allows an event that is commented on with the EVENT tag to be one of seven types: occurrence, state, report, i-action, i-state, i-proverbial. The first five are special cases.

metadata.abstractText: Events of various kinds are mentioned and discussed in text documents, whether they are books, news articles, blogs or microblog feeds. The paper starts by giving an overview of how events are treated in linguistics and philosophy. We follow this discussion by surveying how events and associated information are handled in computationally. In particular, we look at how textual documents can be mined to extract events and ancillary information. These days, it is mostly through the application of various machine learning techniques. We also discuss applications of event detection and extraction systems, particularly in summarization, in the medical domain and in the context of Twitter posts. We end the paper with a discussion of challenges and future directions.
